Award.AwardTitle: Holocene reconstructions of Iceland-Scotland Overflow and the Deep Western Boundary Current
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) can seriously impact regional climate and the global hydrologic cycle. However, variations in this ocean circulation system during the Holocene are poorly understood. The proposed work will address this knowledge gap by generating Holocene-length grain size records with well-constrained chronology, using high-accumulation cores spanning the depth range of the Deep Western Boundary Current (DWBC, or the main pathway by which water sinking in the North Atlantic flows southward at depth). These records will complement similar records from the Iceland-Scotland overflow, helping to define the coupling between the two circulation pathways. In addition, the project will collect cores from both sites to produce more detailed grain size records focusing on the past 2,000 years, when climate forcing is relatively well understood. Interpreted in the context of model sensitivity studies, the records will help to explain the mechanisms and dynamics of long-term AMOC changes during the Holocene.

This research, led by researchers at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, will improve our understanding of and capacity to predict ocean circulation changes that are associated with climate change. The project will support an early-career scientist in establishing a long-term collaboration with senior researchers, and will strengthen international ties via collaboration with scientists from the UK and the Netherlands. A graduate or undergraduate student will be involved in the field campaign.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the project, which included a short cruise south of Iceland to collect marine sediment. and a laboratory component, was to provide a better understanding of how freshwater input into the high latitude North Atlantic (from melting glaciers and/or sea ice) influences the sinking of surface waters to the subsurface. Since freshwater is less dense than salty water, input of fresh water may reduce vertical mixing and inhibit the conversion of surface water to deep water. The conversion of surface water to deep water in the Iceland, Greenland, and Norwegian Seas (the Nordic Seas) and northern North Atlantic and its southward flow at depth in the North Atlantic is linked with the northward transport of heat from lower latitudes and so disruption of this process redistributes heat and influences climate.

Our results suggest that from about 7000 years ago to about 1000 years ago, the decrease in southward flow of water that sank in one northern high-latitude region was typically compensated for by the southward flow of water that sank in another region of the North Atlantic. During this time interval, high latitude northern hemisphere climate became generally colder, sea ice extent increased, and ice export from the Arctic to the Nordic Seas also increased. Our result specifically suggest that while individual components, like Iceland-Scotland Overflow Water, which flows over shallow sills from the Nordic Seas between Iceland and Scotland and sinks into the North Atlantic, decreased as a results of freshwater forcing over this time interval, other components increased. We also focused in greater detail on the last 1000-year history of Iceland-Scotland Overflow Water. We found that the strength of this deep flow since 1750 AD was exceptionally weak by comparison to the rest of the last 7000 years. During this time, the Little Ice Age ended, there was less sea ice export from the Arctic, and the region warmed.  We hypothesize that the melting of Little Ice Age glaciers and sea ice dramatically reduced the conversion of surface to deep water in the Greenland Sea, decreasing the amount of dense water that flowed over the sills into the deep North Atlantic. However, additional work is needed to assess whether the dramatic reduction in Iceland-Scotland Overflow Water since the end of the Little Ice Age was compensated for by an increase in the contribution of other components of deep water. Nevertheless, our results highlight the potentially complex response of conversion of surface to deep water and its southward flow at depth to changes in freshwater forcing, whether produced by changes in the melting rate of glaciers or sea ice, rainfall or river input.

Two graduate students and three undergraduates received training with funding from this grant.
